s.text: While these anti-PG autoantibodies alone do not transfer arthritis, autoantibodies significantly hasten the onset of disease and cause PG to be released from the cartilage [ 6, 7].
While these anti-PG autoantibodies alone do not transfer arthritis, autoantibodies significantly hasten the onset of disease and cause PG to be released from the cartilage [ 6, 7].
While these anti-PG autoantibodies alone do not transfer arthritis, autoantibodies significantly hasten the onset of disease and cause PG to be released from the cartilage [ 6, 7].
In contrast to IgG1, the expression of IgG2a isotype showed a strong inverse correlation with the concentration of endogenous IL-4.
We show here that mice deficient in IL-4 develop arthritis that is significantly more severe than in wild-type animals.

We show here that mice deficient in IL-4 develop arthritis that is significantly more severe than in wild-type animals.
These results show that the PG-specific IgG1 response was marginally dependent on IL-4, whereas endogenous IL-4 dramatically suppressed the PG-specific IgG2a response.
We show here that mice deficient in IL-4 develop arthritis that is significantly more severe than in wild-type animals.

In IFN-?-deficient mice, not only was the proportion of animals with arthritis lower than in the other groups, but also their reduced susceptibility was further mirrored in the significantly less severe paw swelling (Table 1).
We show here that mice deficient in IL-4 develop arthritis that is significantly more severe than in wild-type animals.

The severity of arthritis in each paw was graded according to an established scoring system [ 3, 5] as follows: 0, normal; 1, mild erythema and/or swelling, usually in one or two toes; 2, moderate erythema and/or swelling of the paw; 3, more diffuse erythema; 4, severe erythema and swelling affecting the entire paw (maximum score for the four paws = 16).
In the absence of IL-4, the production of PG-specific IgG2a isotype was dramatically enhanced and disease was significantly more severe.

The severity of arthritis in each paw was graded according to an established scoring system [ 3, 5] as follows: 0, normal; 1, mild erythema and/or swelling, usually in one or two toes; 2, moderate erythema and/or swelling of the paw; 3, more diffuse erythema; 4, severe erythema and swelling affecting the entire paw (maximum score for the four paws = 16).
In the absence of IL-4, the production of PG-specific IgG2a isotype was dramatically enhanced and disease was significantly more severe.
In adjuvant arthritis, which may not be dependent on antibodies, disease is increased in the absence of IL-4 [ 27].
Indeed, the significant reduction of the PG-specific IgG2a response in the absence of IFN-? suggests that the response is controlled by this interferon.
There was a sixfold increase in the IgG2a response in the absence of IL-4 (Fig.
In the absence of IL-4, the IgG2a response was six times greater than in wild-type mice.
